Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award will provide graduate students with the mathematical and computational training necessary to excel in the collaborative world of quantitative bioscience and make a positive impact on society through the application of their research. Quantitative biology is a transformative approach to bioscience and bioengineering research, which embraces a combination of quantitative skills and biological insight applied to previously intractable research problems.

Intellectual Merit: Led by the University of Colorado Biofrontiers Institute, eight science, engineering and math departments will collaborate to address the national need for both interdisciplinary and quantitative training at the graduate level. IQ Biology will create new infrastructure for interdisciplinary graduate programs by providing a mechanism to bring trainees directly into interdisciplinary cohorts and remove hurdles for trainees participating in courses and research that cross departmental and college boundaries. Additionally, trainees will participate in innovation training activities through industry internships, non-academic mentors, symposia, and multidisciplinary team collaborations with faculty and business school colleagues.

Broader Impacts: This IGERT project will help define a new approach to graduate education, catalyze institutional change, foster innovation, encourage global thinking and engage the public in scientific discovery. IQ Biology will create cohorts of graduate students who have disciplinary depth and are uniquely qualified to cross academic boundaries throughout their careers. Building on the University?s commitment to increase diversity in STEM disciplines, IQ Biology works with CU-Boulder?s successful programs to recruit and retain students from underrepresented groups.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to establish new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries, and to engage students in understanding the processes by which research is translated to innovations for societal benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interdisciplinary science is necessary to solve the complex problems arising in modern-day society. The BioFrontiers Institute at CU Boulder was awarded an IGERT for an Interdisciplinary Quantitative Biology (IQ Biology) PhD Program to bring students together from multidisciplinary backgrounds and train them to be leaders in interdisciplinary, bioscience research. From 2011-2018, the program trained 57 student participants and provided additional training opportunities for a broader set of the interdisciplinary research community. Representation of women was strong (39%) compared to US doctoral representation in quantitative fields of approximately 25% in math, computer science, and engineering.

 

IQ Biology students have made broad research contributions and connections across two universities, three colleges, 11 STEM departments, and with over 70 faculty members. IQ Biology students often served as a bridge between faculty labs, fostering increased interdisciplinary research and communication. In addition to completing the IQ Biology program, all IQ Biology students also got/are getting a PhD from one STEM department, where they gain their deep, disciplinary training in a single field, such as Biochemistry or Mechanical Engineering. IQ Biology student PhD research fell into three overlapping research themes: biomedical sciences, novel applications of quantitative tools to biological and social science data, and high-reward interdisciplinary collaborations. As of summer 2018, IQ Biology graduated 15 students with PhDs who went on to work in academia as well as biomedical and data companies, nationally and internationally.

 

In their first year, students participated in high-impact programs that trained them in technical research skills and provided essential content knowledge. A summer bootcamp exposed first-year students to interdisciplinary faculty and research topics and was an introduction to computational skills. It was also a leadership opportunity for second-year students, who (with expert mentorship) led the bootcamp training. In their first year, students also rotated through faculty laboratories doing immersive research projects. Students conducted hands-on experimental and computation work and built research collaborations in disciplines outside their ‘comfort zone.’

 

We developed a specific curriculum program to serve the needs of IQ Biology students. All students took one or more ‘gap-filling’ courses, which were tailored to each student and meant to enhance their knowledge in a secondary STEM discipline. We also developed core courses, like Foundations of Quantitative Biology and Quantitative Optical Imaging. These courses emphasized hands-on technical skills and research-based team work to foster active learning. For example, the course Mathematical and Computational Biology was developed to teach quantitative tools needed in a range of biological fields, and had students directly apply the tools to team research projects.

 

We provided professional development preparation in writing interdisciplinary grant proposals, science communication, networking, team leadership and research collaboration, post-graduate careers, and entrepreneurship. For example, students led a biennial IQ Biology Student Symposium, participated in a Biotech Opportunity seminar series, and accessed the Butcher Innovation Award funds, granted to kick-start collaborative research projects. Students also attended a weekly IQ Biology meet-up to network with faculty and scientists from multiple government and private industries on pointed topics like career paths, data science ethics, cutting-edge research topics, and effective communication. We also developed avenues for students to present their research to scientifically diverse audiences (e.g. travel funding to present at conferences, a Bioinformatics seminar series, laboratory rotation presentations, and the IQ Biology Student Symposium).

 

Trainees were required to do community outreach as part of IQ Biology. They participated in several outreach activities that also disseminated their own research to a broad, community audience, such as mentoring undergraduate, underrepresented students through the CU Boulder SMART program, outreach programs with CU Science Discovery, and participation in an NSF Advanced Technology Education grant with local high schools and community colleges.
